repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Specifically, recommend adding a space after i.e. `--- @see`.

The "space" variant is common for the vast majority of docstring formats
such as doxygen, javadoc and typescript.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
- Lines in the main description start with `--- `
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -234,8 +234,8 @@ definitions.  The |lua-vim| :help is generated from the docstrings.
 Docstring format:
 - Use LuaLS annotations: https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/wiki/Annotations
 - Lines in the main description start with `---`

comment_data.body: This _needs_ to be qualified now (as well as replaced by https://luals.github.io/wiki/annotations/).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -233,9 +233,9 @@ definitions.  The |lua-vim| :help is generated from the docstrings.
 
 Docstring format:
 - Use LuaLS annotations: https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/wiki/Annotations

comment_data.body: I don't understand what qualified means in this context lol. Mind using the suggestion feature to write what you'd like?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -233,9 +233,9 @@ definitions.  The |lua-vim| :help is generated from the docstrings.
 
 Docstring format:
 - Use LuaLS annotations: https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/wiki/Annotations

comment_regular_data.body: I find it a bit weird that we reference the docs from [LuaLS](https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/wiki/Annotations) yet use a different space convention from the examples included there and the completion snippets that the language server generates, but I won't kill anyone about it.

> If the only reason to omit the leading space is to accommodate LuaLS then maybe LuaLS should be patched instead? I don't really like making design decisions based on LuaLS quirks.

LuaLS handles the space just fine (these days); otherwise we'd have had people with pitchforks already. The  issues here, such as they are, are

1. Historical: the OG Lua annotations are [EmmyLua](https://emmylua.github.io/annotations/param.html), which don't contain spaces.
2. Practical: LuaLS is _the_ tool we use for type checking, so it does play a prominent role in our developer guide and setup (`.luacheckrc`), and also defaults to no spaces -- which means that auto-generated docs also contain no spaces, adding (minor) friction when having to massage them manually (based on PR comments).

None of these are a blocker and only mentioned for the sake of completeness.

In any case, this should be automated, ideally using StyLua (which should be powerful enough to do this).

> [LuaLS/lua-language-server#2346](https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/pull/2346)

Won't supporting both make the inconsistency even worse across the ecosystem?
Is this really about consistency, or maybe it's rather about personal aesthetic preferences?

> Won't supporting both make the inconsistency even worse across the ecosystem?

Consistency across the entire Lua eco-system? Sorry that is out of scope. LuaLs already explicitly supports `--- @param`.

> Is this really about consistency, or maybe it's rather about personal aesthetic preferences?

It's about personal readability preferences and consistency within _this_ project.

> Consistency across the entire Lua eco-system? Sorry that is out of scope.

Straw man argument.

> It's about personal readability preferences and consistency within this project.

But this is no convincing argument to be consistent with _your_ personal preference (which you're entitled to, but that is not compelling to anybody else -- especially those with the other preference).

> But this is no convincing argument to be consistent with your personal preference (which you're entitled to, but that is not compelling to anybody else -- especially those with the other preference).

That's what this issue is for. I'm far from the only person who prefers this style.

Also note LuaLS snippets expand the prose as `---comment` (no space), but the repo (LuaLS) itself is wildly inconsistent in this regard.

> Also note LuaLS snippets expand the prose as `---comment` (no space), but the repo (LuaLS) itself is wildly inconsistent in this regard.

This makes me suspect that LuaLS has always omitted the space after _all_ comment characters, which produced the `---@` style accidentally, where it was then adopted widely and is now viewed as "standard".

If LuaLS had always (correctly) added a space character after the `---` comment marker, would we have had `--- @` from the beginning?

Quoting @mfussenegger:

>Habits are powerful and being able to re-use a familiar style reduces cognitive load.

This is _exactly_ my argument for using the space. Space before `@` is a familiar style for anyone who has ever written a Doxygen docstring.

> ideally using StyLua (which should be powerful enough to do this).

It is, but we'd need to submit a PR (it has no plugin system AFAIK)

> This is exactly my argument for using the space. Space before @ is a familiar style for anyone who has ever written a Doxygen docstring.

Fair point. Unfortunately for anyone with a different background it can work the other way around. People with EmmyLua exposure or who came the pure Lua /LuaLS route might have established a different habit.

But I've now also done some more homework and came across things like http://keplerproject.github.io/luadoc/manual.html with `-- @param`, which means in the Lua universe there's more of a mixture of styles than I had assumed.
With that said, I still think that if we want to be able to link to https://luals.github.io/wiki/annotations/ as reference for how to write annotations, somebody making a contributing shouldn't be punished for following that reference.

> I still think that if we want to be able to link to https://luals.github.io/wiki/annotations/ as reference for how to write annotations, somebody making a contributing shouldn't be punished for following that reference.

We agree not to punish anyone :)  For now we're just updating guidance, and we can agree not to nitpick PRs that have either style.

On balance, the "space" variant is common for the _vast_ majority of docstring formats:

- doxygen
- javadoc: https://www.oracle.com/technical-resources/articles/java/javadoc-tool.html
- typescript: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/jsdoc-supported-types.html

So for most contributors, the "no space" variant is going to be unfamiliar. And now that [LuaLs supports the "space" variant](https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/pull/2346), the case for recommending "no space" is weak.
@dundargoc do you plan to update https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#lua-docstrings also here?

> > I still think that if we want to be able to link to https://luals.github.io/wiki/annotations/ as reference for how to write annotations, somebody making a contributing shouldn't be punished for following that reference.
> 
> We agree not to punish anyone :) For now we're just updating guidance, and we can agree not to nitpick PRs that have either style.
> 
> On balance, the "space" variant is common for the _vast_ majority of docstring formats:
> 
> * doxygen
> * javadoc: https://www.oracle.com/technical-resources/articles/java/javadoc-tool.html
> * typescript: https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/jsdoc-supported-types.html
> 
> So for most contributors, the "no space" variant is going to be unfamiliar. And now that [LuaLs supports the "space" variant](https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/pull/2346), the case for recommending "no space" is weak.

Fair enough,  I'll just pretend that the rationale is "we really like spaces", because that's easier for me to swallow than "we reduce consistency with other lua projects to increase consistency with non-lua projects"

(Read: I yield, change is fine for me and Dogtown has higher priority than spaces)

title: docs: change lua style guide regarding doc comments
